awd_titl_txt: Structure and thermal elastic properties of calcium silicate perovskite
awd_abstract_narration:
Calcium silicate perovskite (CaPv) occurs as the third most abundant phase in the Earth’s lower mantle, next to (Mg,Fe)SiO3 bridgmanite and (Mg,Fe)O. It is considered a candidate mineral to explain some lower-mantle seismic observations and anomalies, as well as the main host for large cations in the lower mantle. Seismic properties of CaPv at mantle conditions, however, remain poorly constrained, as there are often contradictory theoretical and experimental predictions and determinations in the literature. Experiments and calculations have revealed multiple crystal structures of CaPv, but its phase transition boundary and elastic properties in the pressure-temperature-composition (P-T-X) space of relevance to the mantle are still under debate. This project will contribute to the following fundamental questions: (1) the fate of subducted oceanic crust and CaPv’s roles in lower mantle mineralogy and seismology, and (2) the origin of mantle’s seismic anomalies and heterogeneity. The project will directly contribute to the training of one graduate student at in-house laboratory and large synchrotron facilities and will also actively involve two early-career scientists. The research team will continue to mentor undergraduate students or high school students, particularly traditionally underrepresented minorities, i.e., Native Hawaiians and other Pacific Islanders, to study geosciences and planetary sciences by active involvement in ongoing research. The results from the proposed project will be disseminated via publications, national and international meetings, public lectures and news media.

The proposed project aims to accurately measure the crystal structure and identify the phase transition boundary of (Al,Ti)-bearing CaSiO3 pervoskite in the P-T-X space of Earth’s mantle, employing laser-heated and externally-heated diamond anvil cell (EHDAC) and synchrotron X-ray diffraction techniques. The team will approach this goal by developing in-situ methods of growing non-quenchable silicate single crystals, and combining single-crystal/multigrain X-ray diffraction measurements with a newly developed EHDAC setups to reach temperatures above 1200 K. The proposed research aims to (1) determine the crystal structure and phase transformations of pure and (Ti,Al)-bearing CaPv, and (2) measure the thermal equation of state of CaPv at pressure-temperature conditions relevant to Earth's transition zone and lower mantle. The proposed measurements on the crystallographic phase transitions and thermal elastic properties of CaSiO3 will break open a bottleneck on the quest into the mantle mineralogy, and thus offer new understanding of CaPv’s contribution in elucidating the lower-mantle seismic observations and anomalies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

por.por_cntn:
Calcium silicate perovskite (CaSiO₃) is one of the most abundant minerals in Earth’s lower mantle, playing a key role in how seismic waves travel through the deep Earth. However, its physical and chemical properties at extreme pressures and temperatures remain poorly understood. This NSF-funded research investigated how CaSiO₃ behaves under high-pressure and high-temperature conditions similar to those found deep inside our planet.

Our research focused on determining the crystal structure, phase transitions, and elasticity of CaSiO₃, particularly when it contains titanium (Ti). Through high-pressure experiments using diamond anvil cells and synchrotron X-ray diffraction, we found that Ti-bearing CaSiO₃ perovskite is less dense than pure CaSiO₃, which suggests it may influence how subducted oceanic crust behaves in the lower mantle. This discovery helps explain why some seismic anomalies—such as Large Low Shear Velocity Provinces (LLSVPs)—appear in deep Earth imaging. To conduct these experiments, we developed new high-pressure-temperature techniques, including the Externally-Heated Diamond Anvil Cell Experimentation (EH-DANCE) system, which allows scientists to study materials at temperatures above 1400 K while under extreme pressure. This innovative tool has expanded the ability to explore mineral physics and planetary interiors. The EH-DANCE system was successfully tested at multiple beamlines, including at Advanced Photon Source (APS) at Argonne National Lab, Advanced Light Source (ALS) at Berkeley Lab and SPring-8 synchrotron facilities in Japan. Additionally, we designed a specialized laser-heating method to study transparent CaSiO₃, which does not absorb infrared lasers directly. Using a boron-doped diamond layer as a laser absorber, we were able to measure the thermal equation of state of Ti-bearing CaSiO₃ up to 75 GPa and 2430 K. Our findings confirmed that Ti-bearing CaSiO₃ undergoes a phase transition at a significantly higher temperature (around 1300 K) compared to pure CaSiO₃ (around 500 K), providing new insights into how this mineral behaves inside Earth.

Beyond advancing scientific knowledge, this project contributed to training the next generation of Earth scientists. Graduate student Keng-Hsien Chao completed his Ph.D. research on this topic and successfully defended his dissertation in 2024. Other students and postdoctoral researchers were trained in high-pressure experimental techniques and synchrotron X-ray diffraction, equipping them with valuable skills for future research. Our results were shared with the broader scientific community through publications in leading journals, presentations at major conferences like the AGU Fall Meeting, and collaborations with research institutions worldwide. The new EH-DANCE experimental setup is now available for other researchers to use at ALS and APS, opening new opportunities for high-pressure studies in geophysics, planetary science, and materials research.

This research has significantly improved our understanding of calcium silicate perovskite and its role in Earth’s deep interior. The findings help explain key seismic features in the lower mantle and contribute to better models of mantle convection and planetary evolution. The technological advancements developed in this project will continue to support cutting-edge research in high-pressure science for studying planetary interiors under extreme conditions.
